expectations:
- MUST be in US English

      
  - It should assume learners start with no prior knowledge of the subject
  - Should create a progressive learning path going from basic/beginner to mastery of the subject
  - By the end of this course, they should be able to lead very complex projects and tasks in this field
  - They should be prepared for certifications or advanced studies in this subject like a master's degree or PhD
  - Should include **EVERYTHING** a student needs to be at the top 1% of the field
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Should cover latest trends in the field
  - Don't use vendors in chapter titles or descriptions (e.g. "npm", "yarn", "Redux", etc.)
    - Except are for widely known tools related to the course (e.g. "Git" in a programming course)
  - This is an eval system for a learning platform, of course the definition of "ready for a job" doesn't mean they have the legal requirements to work in the field (eg. medical license, law license, etc.). That's not important here, we're assessing if the course prepares the student with the necessary knowledge and skills.
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality.
  - Titles should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - Just "HTML" is better than "HTML Structure and Semantics" (structure and semantics are implied if this is the only HTML chapter). Similarly, if we only have one CSS chapter, just "CSS" is better than "CSS Styling and Layout".
    - "Front-end frameworks" is better than "Front-End UI Frameworks Overview" (too verbose) or "Front-End Frameworks: Core Concepts" (core concepts is unnecessary fluff)
    - "Relational Databases" is better than "Relational Databases and SQL" (SQL is implied, no need to mention)
    - "Introduction to Java" is better than "Introduction to Java and Setting Up Your Development Environment" (too verbose)
    - "Lean Startup" is better than "The Lean Startup Methodology: An Overview" (too verbose)
    - "Introduction to X" is valid for titles of introductory chapters but we should avoid those words in descriptions
  - Similarly, descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - "Styling with CSS: Selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." is better than "Master styling and layout with CSS, including selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." - "Master" is fluff, and so are words like "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.
    - "Properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." is better than "Explore the definition of Chemistry, properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." - "Explore the definition of Chemistry" are filler/unnecessary words.
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises
  - It shouldn't mention in title or description references to 1% or similar instructions about being top 1%

rankings.reasoning: Model F has 213 chapters, making it the most comprehensive curriculum. It covers an exceptional breadth and depth: mathematical foundations, micro theory, macro theory, econometrics (with granular coverage of methods like IV, DID, RDD, synthetic controls, matching, quantile regression, nonparametric/semiparametric, duration models), applied fields (health, education, crime, family, urban, housing, transport, agricultural, energy, climate, environmental, resource), IO, labor, public finance (broken into commodity/income/corporate taxation plus compliance), development, trade, international finance, financial economics, behavioral economics, game theory, mechanism design, contract theory, political economy, and professional skills. It also covers modern/frontier topics like digital economy, privacy economics, crypto/DeFi, geoeconomics (missing though), behavioral macro, expectations/information frictions, heterogeneous-agent models, spatial equilibrium, firm dynamics, productivity measurement, culture and economics, gender economics, race and economics, intergenerational economics, aging economics. The titles are generally concise and follow the prompt guidelines well. Descriptions are direct without filler words. It includes career chapters plus graduate study preparation and interview preparation. It covers data management, reproducibility, visualization, computational methods, and text-as-data. Some minor issues: having separate chapters for 'simple regression' and 'multiple regression' plus 'robust inference' is very granular on basic econometrics; a few chapters like 'Crypto and DeFi economics' are somewhat niche. It includes chapters on philosophy of economics, history of economic thought, and ethics. The math foundations section (calculus, linear algebra, optimization, dynamic programming, optimal control) is thorough. Overall, this is the most complete and well-structured curriculum.

Model B has 170 chapters with excellent coverage. It is well-organized with clear progression from foundations through micro, macro, econometrics, applied fields, and professional skills. Strengths include: granular econometric coverage (DID, RDD, synthetic controls, matching, causal ML, structural models, discrete choice, dynamic structural models, empirical auctions), strong applied micro coverage (health with separate insurance/provider chapters, education, crime, family, urban, transport, agricultural, energy, climate, environmental), modern topics (digital economy, data/privacy, automation/future of work, geoeconomics, pandemic economics, defense economics, green macroeconomics), and good macro coverage (HANK, DSGE methods, VAR/SVAR, state-space). Titles are concise and professional. Descriptions avoid filler. It covers nowcasting, forecasting, economic communication, ethics, and careers. Some gaps: mathematical foundations are less explicit (constrained optimization and probability are covered but no dedicated linear algebra, calculus, or dynamic programming chapters). However, for an economics curriculum this may be appropriate as math is often considered prerequisite. The coverage of development economics is thorough with separate chapters on institutions, credit, technology adoption, and firms. Overall very strong and comprehensive.

Model G has 125 chapters and is very thorough, particularly strong on mathematical foundations (4 chapters on math including real analysis and measure theory), computational methods (agent-based modeling, numerical methods for heterogeneous-agent models, simulation), and advanced theory (dynamic contracts, regulation under asymmetric information, advanced general equilibrium with incomplete markets). It has excellent research skills coverage including grant writing, presentation skills, and replication standards. However, there are some issues: some titles are verbose (e.g., 'Mathematical Foundations II: Multivariable Calculus & Optimization', 'Game Theory III: Incomplete Information and Signaling'), which goes against the concise title guideline. Several chapters use 'Special Topics in...' framing which is somewhat vague. The last chapter is titled 'Synthesis of Methods for Independent Research' which reads like a capstone project, violating the no-capstone rule. Some applied fields get less granular coverage (inequality, poverty, gender economics are somewhat thin). The career section has multiple chapters including interview preparation and personal branding, which is thorough but perhaps excessive. Overall strong but with formatting issues and some organizational weaknesses.

Model E has 120 chapters with solid coverage across all major areas. It progresses logically from micro through macro, international, financial economics, applied fields, econometrics, and professional skills. Strengths: good coverage of financial economics (CAPM, derivatives, behavioral finance), comprehensive applied fields (health, education, urban, environmental, climate, agricultural, crime, family/gender, immigration, happiness/well-being, law and economics), good econometric coverage, and modern topics (digital economy, AI, cryptocurrency). Descriptions are generally concise and informative. Some weaknesses: mathematical foundations are limited to just two chapters (Mathematical Methods and Dynamic Optimization) which appear late in the curriculum; the micro theory section, while solid, doesn't separate some topics as granularly as competitors; some descriptions are slightly verbose (e.g., the Unemployment chapter description). The curriculum covers happiness economics and law and economics which some competitors miss. The OLG and Ramsey models get dedicated attention. Overall a well-rounded curriculum but slightly less granular than the top competitors in econometrics and some applied areas.

Model C has 147 chapters with very strong coverage, particularly in microeconomic theory, financial economics, and industrial organization. Unique strengths: it includes monopsony as a separate chapter, has dedicated chapters for cost minimization and profit maximization using duality theory (Shephard's lemma, Hotelling's lemma), covers specific factors model in trade, and has comprehensive financial economics (time value of money, CAPM, APT, EMH, fixed income, derivatives, corporate finance, behavioral finance, market microstructure). The IO coverage is excellent with separate chapters on market power measurement, advanced pricing, product differentiation models, entry/deterrence, and collusion. Development economics coverage includes agricultural economics, credit markets, health/education, and RCTs. Economic history is well covered with separate chapters on Industrial Revolution, Great Depression, and post-WWII. It includes complexity economics, evolutionary economics, neuroeconomics, and demographic economics. Career guidance is split into three focused chapters (academic, public policy, private sector). Weaknesses: mathematical foundations are not explicitly covered in dedicated chapters; the econometric section, while solid, could be more granular on some modern methods (no synthetic control, no causal ML chapter); some titles could be more concise. The descriptions are generally good but a few could be tighter. Overall very comprehensive with excellent depth in several areas.

Model A has 133 chapters with good comprehensive coverage. It follows a logical progression from micro foundations through macro, international economics, development, applied fields, econometrics, and professional skills. Strengths: well-organized macro section with clear progression through IS-LM, Phillips Curve, expectations, New Classical, New Keynesian, and DSGE; good international economics coverage including gravity model, Mundell-Fleming, impossible trinity, and currency crises; solid development economics with multiple focused chapters. The history of economic thought is covered across multiple chapters (Classical to Marxist, Neoclassical, Keynesian to Modern). Applied fields cover health, education, crime, family, urban, regional, environmental, and climate economics. Some weaknesses: mathematical foundations have no dedicated chapters; financial economics is relatively thin (one chapter on financial economics and asset pricing plus one on risk); the econometrics section is solid but missing some modern methods like synthetic controls; some descriptions could be more concise. Titles are generally good and follow guidelines. The curriculum is well-balanced but not as granular as the top competitors in several areas.

Model D has 116 chapters, making it the smallest curriculum among competitors. While it covers the major areas, several topics receive less granular treatment. Strengths: clear logical progression, good coverage of microeconomic theory with separate chapters for each oligopoly model (Cournot, Bertrand, Stackelberg), separate chapters for static and dynamic games, and good public finance coverage. Weaknesses: mathematical foundations are absent as dedicated chapters; development economics is condensed into just two chapters; international economics coverage is relatively thin; the econometrics section lacks some modern methods (no matching methods, limited causal ML coverage); financial economics has only CAPM and EMH chapters without derivatives, corporate finance theory, or market microstructure; applied fields like transportation, energy, agricultural economics get minimal or no coverage; behavioral economics is split across heuristics/biases, prospect theory, and nudge theory but lacks behavioral game theory or behavioral macro; no dedicated chapters on computational methods, data visualization, or reproducibility. Some titles are verbose (e.g., 'Elasticity and Its Applications'). The descriptions are generally adequate but some include filler. At 116 chapters, this curriculum has notable gaps compared to competitors and doesn't achieve the same depth of coverage needed for mastery.

Model F provides an exceptional, highly comprehensive curriculum of 161 chapters. It perfectly captures the progression required to reach the top 1% (PhD level) by strategically including essential mathematical and statistical foundations (Real Analysis, Dynamic Programming, Linear Algebra) before diving into advanced microeconomics, macroeconomics, and econometrics. It includes modern, cutting-edge topics (HANK models, DSGE, Causal Machine Learning) and follows all formatting and negative constraints flawlessly.

Model B is outstanding, offering 131 chapters with a highly logical progression. Like Model F, it introduces quantitative literacy, constrained optimization, and probability early on to prepare the learner for advanced concepts. It goes deep into structural modeling, heterogeneous-agent macro, and modern causal inference. The titles and descriptions are perfectly concise and free of fluff.

Model C is a very strong curriculum with 120 chapters that covers both introductory concepts and advanced PhD-level topics (e.g., Aiyagari models, Ramsey-Cass-Koopmans, advanced DSGE). While it is excellent, it slightly trails Models F and B because it lacks the dedicated foundational math chapters needed to bridge the gap between intermediate economics and the highly quantitative advanced topics it includes.

Model A provides a solid, extensive curriculum of 114 chapters. It covers a broad range of micro, macro, econometric, and field topics. The descriptions and titles are concise and adhere strictly to the negative constraints. It is slightly less deep in state-of-the-art PhD-level methodology compared to the higher-ranked models.

Model D offers a well-structured curriculum of 103 chapters. It covers the fundamentals and field courses effectively and meets all constraints. However, it is the shortest curriculum and doesn't reach the same level of granular depth in modern, top 1% level topics as the leading models.

Model E provides a good curriculum of 107 chapters, but it has some logical progression issues. For instance, it places 'Mathematical Methods for Economics' and 'Dynamic Optimization' near the very end of the course, which are foundational tools needed to understand the structural econometrics and advanced macro models taught earlier in its path. It otherwise follows the formatting rules well.

Model G builds a very rigorous and advanced curriculum that would otherwise score highly. However, it explicitly includes a capstone chapter ('Capstone research skills review...' in the description for 'Synthesis of Methods for Independent Research'), which directly violates a critical negative constraint in the prompt ('No assessments, projects, or capstones').

Most comprehensive and closest to the prompt’s intent (top-to-bottom path to mastery). Provides far more granular coverage than others, spanning math foundations, micro/macro, econometrics (including modern causal inference, ML, text/geospatial), computation/reproducibility, applied fields, and modern topics (platforms, privacy, crypto, industrial policy, climate transition). Titles/descriptions are mostly concise and professional, with minimal fluff and good progression from foundations to advanced/modern practice, plus career/grad-prep chapters.

Very strong breadth and modernity with clear, job/PhD-relevant depth: strong micro theory, macro (including HANK, crises), extensive causal inference toolkit (DiD, RDD, synthetic control, double ML), computational/ABM, and contemporary topics (geoeconomics, pandemics, data/privacy, automation, green macro). Progression is coherent and descriptions are generally tight. Main drawback: still far short of the prompt’s implied 100+ chapter expectation and slightly less coverage of mathematical foundations than the best entry.

Broad and advanced, with explicit math/stat foundations (including real analysis, stochastic processes, measure theory), strong theory/metrics/computation, and multiple policy/practice chapters plus careers. However, it’s packaged into relatively few, very wide chapters (not granular), includes a few questionable/awkward items (e.g., “Mathematical Foundations I: Calculus” description mentions proofs more than calculus; final “Synthesis…Capstone” reads like a capstone despite the ‘no capstones’ rule), and overall still does not meet the “100+ chapters” guidance.

Solid, accurate, and fairly broad across micro/macro/international/development/metrics with some modern topics (ML, platforms, complexity, climate). Good readability and progression from intro through advanced. Key weakness: only ~100? actually ~100-ish? (it is under 100; roughly 90s) and still missing several important modern empirical/practical areas compared to the best (research integrity, reproducibility standards, modern DiD pitfalls, synthetic control, state-space/nowcasting, more computation).

Good conventional economics coverage with some modern additions (AI economics, crypto/DeFi, MMT mention) and includes math methods and research reading/writing plus careers. But many chapters are broad/combined, overall count is well below the prompt’s typical 100+ expectation, and several descriptions are too long and list-like, drifting from the “concise, straight to the point” guidance.

Technically solid and fairly advanced (strong micro theory, macro models, econometrics, finance, development, environment, complexity). Includes career chapters. Main issues: still far under 100 chapters; some redundancy/imbalances (heavy on finance relative to other applied fields), and a few titles/descriptions feel more graduate-theory-centric without enough scaffolding for true zero-prior learners beyond the first few chapters.

Covers core micro/macro/trade/metrics and some applied fields, but it is notably less comprehensive and less modern than the stronger entries, with fewer chapters and less coverage of current methods (modern causal inference ecosystem, ML beyond a single mention, reproducibility, big data, platform/privacy, geoeconomics, nowcasting). Some repetition (e.g., CAPM/EMH appear twice) and overall granularity is limited.
